description: From Middle English vacation, vacacion, vacacioun, from Anglo-Norman vacacioun, from Old French vacacion, vacation, from Latin vacātiō. Equivalent to vacate +‎ -ion.

entries.meaning: Freedom from some business or activity. [from 14th c.]
(obsolete) Free time given over to a specific purpose; occupation, activity. [15th–17th c.]
A period during which official activity or business is formally suspended; an official holiday from university, law courts etc. [from 15th c.]
(Canada, US) A holiday; a stretch of leisure time away from work or duty and devoted to rest or pleasure. [from 19th c.]
An extended period of time away from work or school.
examples: Spring vacation offers a good opportunity to travel.

entries.meaning: The act of vacating something; moving out. [from 19th c.]
examples: The Conservative Party’s vacation of the centre ground gave an opportunity to its opponents.

entries.meaning: (US, law) The act of making legally void.

verbs.description: vacation (third-person singular simple present vacations, present participle vacationing, simple past and past participle vacationed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To spend or take a vacation.
examples: This year, we’re vacationing in Mexico.
